user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of check_connection_reply:
```c
static void
check_connection_reply (struct MHD_Connection *connection)
{
  struct MHD_Connection *const c = connection; /**< a short alias */
  struct MHD_Response *const r = c->rp.response;  /**< a short alias */

  mhd_assert (c->rp.props.set);
#ifdef HAVE_MESSAGES
  if ( (! c->rp.props.use_reply_body_headers) &&
       (0 != r->total_size) )
  {
    MHD_DLOG (c->daemon,
              _ ("This reply with response code %u cannot use reply body. "
                 "Non-empty response body is ignored and not used.\n"),
              (unsigned) (c->rp.responseCode));
  }
  if ( (! c->rp.props.use_reply_body_headers) &&
       (0 != (r->flags_auto & MHD_RAF_HAS_CONTENT_LENGTH)) )
  {
    MHD_DLOG (c->daemon,
              _ ("This reply with response code %u cannot use reply body. "
                 "Application defined \"Content-Length\" header violates"
                 "HTTP specification.\n"),
              (unsigned) (c->rp.responseCode));
  }
#else
  (void) c; /* Mute compiler warning */
  (void) r; /* Mute compiler warning */
#endif
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
suspicious_frags:
#else
  (void) c; /* Mute compiler warning */
  (void) r; /* Mute compiler warning */
#endif
explanation: Other fragments do not appear to present unreachable-code concerns and therefore need not be investigated: - The local alias declarations (struct MHD_Connection *const c = connection; and struct MHD_Response *const r = c->rp.response;) are simple initializations and do not introduce unreachable code. - There are no return statements, unconditional gotos, infinite loops, or code following an unconditional abort/exit within this function except for the mhd_assert macro (which is listed above because its expansion could change control flow). - The conditional compilation boundary (the #ifdef/#else/#endif) itself is normal and only controls whether logging or the (void) casts are compiled; the (void) casts are legitimate to suppress unused-variable warnings when logging is omitted and are included above for inspection. - There are no constant boolean expressions in plain code (e.g., if (0) or if (1)) that would make blocks unconditionally unreachable. Therefore, apart from the listed fragments (assert, the two logging branches and the no-logging (void) casts), no other parts of this function warrant investigation for potential unreachable code.
